provenance:
Michaelis Israelski (1874–1963), Berlin, by 1926 [see note 1]. Private Collection, before 1958. Possibly Dr. Fritz Rothmann (dealer, 1893–1983), London, by 1959; possibly sold to Galerie Fischer, Lucerne, Switzerland, September 2, 1959 [sale, Galerie Fischer, Lucerne, November 24–30, 1959, lot 2043 (unsold)] [see note 2]. S.F. Arnold, Munich; sold through Dieter Glocker, Wehen im Taunus, Germany, Monika Schaefer (nee Winter, died 2019) and Dr. Herbert Schaefer (1910–2011), Malaga, Spain, August 18, 1969 (on loan to the Hamburger Kunsthalle, Hamburg, Germany, to 1977) (on loan to the Norton Simon Collection, Pasadena, 1978–81) (on loan to the Yale University Art Gallery, New Haven, Conn., 1981–2019); bequeathed to the Yale University Art Gallery, New Haven, Conn., 2020

Note 1: “Thomas” was exhibited within the 1926 Lovis Corinth exhibition at the Nationalgalerie, Berlin, a loan from the collection of “Herr M. Israelski.” According to correspondence from the exhibition, Herr Israelski lived in Charlottenburg-Westend, Berlin, Bayernallee 36. In addition to “Thomas,” he loaned a second painting by Corinth, “Flieder,” 1919, cat. no. 305.  (Letter from “M. Israelski,” to the Nationalgalerie, Berlin, January 12, 1926, courtesy Zentralarchiv, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, copy in accession file). In May 1943, Israelski sold “Flieder” to the Galerie St. Etienne, New York (Letter from Dr. Otto Kallir, Galerie St. Etienne, New York, to Mr. M. Israelski, Los Angeles, May 13, 1943, courtesy Kallir Research Institute, New York, copy in accession file). Research conducted by the Gallery in 2023 has shown “M. Israelski” to be Michaelis Israelski (later Michael Illing, 1874–1963), a merchant, and founder and director of Israelski & Robinson AG., a footwear wholesaler in Berlin. 

Note 2: According to records of the Galerie Fischer, Lucerne, on September 2, 1959, Galerie Fischer bought an unspecified painting by Lovis Corinth from a “Mr. Dr. Rothmann, London.” As the painting of Thomas was subsequently consigned to auction in November 1959 by the Galerie, it is possible the Galerie Fischer bought the painting in September and tried to sell it in November (Email from Galerie Fischer Archive, Lucerne, to the Gallery, March 21, 2024, copy in accession file)

Note 3: According to records of the Galerie Fischer, Lucerne, the painting was consigned to auction from Galerie Fischer’s stock (Email from Galerie Fischer Archive, Lucerne, to the Gallery, October 6, 2021, copy in accession file)
